channel.title: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @xEthanx xEthanx
item.description:
@xEthanx wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:10, topic:540905”]If you had read the forth reply in this topic you’ll know that the problem had already been solved a while ago, thanks anyhow
And the class wasn’t just to load the text of a file, it had lots of other functions. And what if I did create it just to read the text of a file? What would be superfluous about it? It was a rather big project so I didn’t want to write code to read from a text file in a class which has not much to do with that. Just using it in a static context like Map = IO.getMap(); is a great way to keep a nice overview on your code.[/quote]
I see it as superfluous because I assumed you only needed to do it one time. The interface is nice like you said to be able to reference it like that but if you’re only trying to read a map file one time it just seems like a waste of code to me. I like programs written as simple as possible so if needed to distribute for others to see, they won’t be asking why the hell a whole new class was made or the design is just over the top, that’s all. But hey, we all choose to do things differently.

But yeah, if you’re using it for other functions as well then yeah I guess it makes sense.

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

i’m saying that none of this has anything to do with garbage collection or efficiency. this man is taking a course on object oriented design, not compiler design.

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Justin Bieber:

posts you quoted have nothing to do with garbage collection, or efficiency at all. if someone says something is unnecessary I assume they’re referring to overly complex design

They OP wants to not create an object. I said create one. The person I was replying to said that the object would only get used once. I’m saying that does not matter because the garbage collector would sort that out for us.

What don’t you understand?

Read full topic

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:12, topic:540905”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=659771.msg4421942#msg4421942 date=1398876527]

[quote author=Pure_ link=topic=659771.msg4411855#msg4411855 date=1394050220]

Why don’t you want to “create an object”?
[/quote]Doesn’t seem necessary in the given context, the object is probably only accessed once too.

You clearly don’t know how the garbage collector works.
[/quote]GC has nothing to do with code structure/style[/quote]
Read post, if the OP did create an object it would get destroyed by the garbage collector.

Read full topic

item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:9, topic:540905”]Wait - you’re creating an entire new class to read a text file? I’m confused. Unless I misunderstood, that’s really superfluous. If all you’re trying to do is read characters from a text file there’s absolutely nothing wrong with a BufferedReader with a FileReader inside, which would maybe take up 10-20 lines of code max.

BufferedReaders are great for performance as they can read through huge text files at incredible speeds. If that is all you’re trying to do, I’d have a look at this article.

EDIT: If you really refuse my advice though, just change your “getClass()” to “Classname.class” right before the “.getResource()”.[/quote]

If you had read the forth reply in this topic you’ll know that the problem had already been solved a while ago, thanks anyhow
And the class wasn’t just to load the text of a file, it had lots of other functions. And what if I did create it just to read the text of a file? What would be superfluous about it? It was a rather big project so I didn’t want to write code to read from a text file in a class which has not much to do with that. Just using it in a static context like Map = IO.getMap(); is a great way to keep a nice overview on your code.

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @xEthanx xEthanx
item.description:
@xEthanx wrote:

Wait - you’re creating an entire new class to read a text file? I’m confused. Unless I misunderstood, that’s really superfluous. If all you’re trying to do is read characters from a text file there’s absolutely nothing wrong with a BufferedReader with a FileReader inside, which would maybe take up 10-20 lines of code max.

BufferedReaders are great for performance as they can read through huge text files at incredible speeds. If that is all you’re trying to do, I’d have a look at this article.

EDIT: If you really refuse my advice though, just change your “getClass()” to “Classname.class” right before the “.getResource()”.

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Ferty Ferty
item.description:
@Ferty wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:4, topic:540905”][quote author=Snow_ link=topic=659771.msg4411803#msg4411803 date=1394020478]
Thanks for your reply, but I don’t really understand how a singleton pattern would help?
And due to it being rather imperative programming I’m not going to use it as our course is called ‘Object Oriented Programming’…
[/quote]Just make the function static, not the entire class.[/quote]

This.

You don’t need to instantiate a class to access it’s static methods (assuming they are not private); they are accessed via the class name as opposed to an object reference.

ClassFoo.staticmethod(derp);

Hell you could even do:

import static SomeClass;

and access all of that classes static(class) methods/fields as if they were in the class you’re working on.

  • Edit -
    Unless of course you are referencing a static inner class. Static inner classes can be instantiated without an instance of the containing class.

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:4, topic:540905”][quote author=Snow_ link=topic=659771.msg4411803#msg4411803 date=1394020478]
Thanks for your reply, but I don’t really understand how a singleton pattern would help?
And due to it being rather imperative programming I’m not going to use it as our course is called ‘Object Oriented Programming’…
[/quote]Just make the function static, not the entire class.[/quote]

The reason I made the function / class static was that I wouldn’t have to create a new object to use the function. If I would make only the function static, I would still have this problem since I’m not instantiating the class

Thanks anyhow!

But I’ve found the solution.
I just had to replace getClass() by class().

I’ve already tried that and thought it was wrong.
Now I realise I was looking at it the wrong way and that it actually works… (:

But the reason it wouldn’t work earlier was that I had a space character in the path!

If I printed out the path it would replace the space character by a ‘%20’ (hex for 32, which is it’s ASCII code!)

I solved the problem by simply removing the space character.
But… if I really wanted to keep the space for some reason, would the best solution be finding the path this way and then converting the %20 to a space character?

Read full topic

item.title: Java relative path of a static class
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

Hello everyone!

For my ‘tanks’ game which I am developing in Java I need to read a text file in which the map’s data is stored.
I made a new class for this called ‘MapReader’.
However, I would like to be able to use the ‘read’ function of the class without instantiating a new MapReader object.
That’s why I made it a static class.

Now my problem is that I can’t seem to find a way to get the relative path which is needed to load the file.
If it weren’t static I would just be able to use new File(getClass().getResource("/maps/map.txt"));

Read full topic
item.source: Java relative path of a static class
